body: Add `system-test` to https://github.com/poplav/incubator-toree/blob/jupyter_kernel_tests/Makefile#L278 and https://github.com/poplav/incubator-toree/blob/jupyter_kernel_tests/Makefile#L276

We also need to consider multi-line comments (`/*`) if we're going to filter out that way. Might be a better idea to use regex to remove comments from the full code blob before splitting. `//` matches to newline and `/*` matches until `*/`. E.g.

``` scala
val x = 3 /*
some comment
*/ val y = 4
// another comment
z = 5 // final comment?
// no, this is the final comment
```

becomes

``` scala
val x = 3
val y = 4
val z = 5
```

Would also be a good idea to have some sort of test (maybe system?) that can verify that providing comments does not provide an empty syntax error like you've seen.

@Lull3rSkat3r, @lbustelo, feel free to chime in on this one with your own thoughts.
agreed üéê
@lbustelo comments should be resolved by the latest commit
I wonder is there is code in some Apache package to do this rather than rely on regex or string lookups directly.
@poplav Can you rename this into a `[WIP]`? I think there is more work to do here.
Thanks!  In addition, we've modified the Brunel magic to move out of the Toree namespace, updated to compile against latest Toree and confirmed this works.  We will release this change in Brunel 1.2.
I tested running system test locally and works good. Will merge.
@chipsenkbeil I merged #39. You should be able to add the plugin test using the kernel tester.

@lbustelo, @poplav, I haven't looked at how the system tests are set up yet. How difficult is it going to be to get a jar in the system tests? I want to be able to add a magic using %AddJar and verify that it works and don't want anything related to the network to be involved.

@chipsenkbeil , The system tests are [run](https://github.com/apache/incubator-toree/blob/master/Makefile#L181) in a docker container.  You should be able to volume mount some sort of test resources dir [here](https://github.com/apache/incubator-toree/blob/master/Makefile#L184) and operate normally.  You would put your test case as is [here](https://github.com/apache/incubator-toree/blob/master/test_toree.py#L41).  I assume this, but have not tested it yet.  
My main concern is as of now those tests  run code and expect an exact output.  In the case of AddJar unpredictable output might occur, but that is probably not the case because it would be local/not network.  Is there a way to suppress output for certain lines? If so that may help.
@poplav, can you provide code and ignore the result? I don't care about the output cell of the `%AddJar` call. I want to instead test the resulting side effect.
Sounds good to me. @lbustelo, since the jupyter tests aren't quite ready for me to add this specific test, can I go ahead and merge this?
@chipsenkbeil Open a JIRA to add the system test and place it on the 0.1.0 release bucket.

@danrope @chipsenkbeil

![magic_plugin_works](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2474841/15396988/0eea740c-1da4-11e6-8a0e-ac888ad1927e.gif)

Will merge and push a dev8 out.
Okay tests pass.  Let me know what else is needed, not entirely sure how to test the authentication other than mocking it and not sure if there is substantial benefit in that

FYI, to test authentication in coursier, I run a small web server on localhost requiring authentication, and use it from the tests. The server is launched [here](https://github.com/alexarchambault/coursier/blob/0d79cf0ed1e66f1eb9a68de0d5d641b2c4d5fbe9/.ci/travis.sh#L33-L40) (`1.0.0-SNAPSHOT` can be replaced by `1.0.0-M12`).

@mariusvniekerk, just realized this has a WIP on it. Are you still working on this? Or is it ready to be merged?
I'm done. Want me to rename?
@mariusvniekerk, looks like it doesn't merge cleanly. Would you mind rebasing your branch? Otherwise, we lose a bit of tracking with Apache's git bot.

@lbustelo, [TOREE-318 (about the pyspark interpreter execute result)](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/TOREE-318) is almost done.  I am planning on adding kernel tests for that similar to what is here, thus want to make sure this looks right before continuing. [Edit] @chipsenkbeil if this looks good can you merge it.

Deferring to @lbustelo after pointing out the local copy of `lwjgl-3.0.0b.jar`. Originally, we were verifying that downloading a jar worked along with adding it. Hosting it locally removes the network risk but also removes the test involving checking that downloading works.

So, do we want to a) test a local jar or a network jar and b) do we want to continue using lwjgl or switch to our own jar?
Amended the commit to download the jar instead of using it locally.
@lbustelo, @Lull3rSkat3r, this is pretty nice considering sbt 1.0+ has removed support for `Build.scala` in favor of `build.sbt`. So, we'll need to do this eventually.

@lbustelo, @Lull3rSkat3r, do either of you remember why we explicitly brought in Guava? Was it for magic loading? If it still compiles and there are no issues with the system tests, then I guess it's fine, but wanted to make sure.

LGTM, the only feedback I have is about the `BuildInfo` class. It looks like the package name was changed. If we can we should not move the package as to not break any references people have to that class. Otherwise great job!
I've rewritten history and moved the BuildInfo package back to org.apache.toree.kernel.

@chipsenkbeil Can you give this a final review and merge?  This is hosting system-test resources (`TestJar.jar`) in the system test container using a python http.server.  This was the jar we already were using for testing in `scala-interpreter/src/test/resources/`.
LGTM

Interesting. It's been awhile since the lazy Spark Context initialization support was added. Clearly, the shutdown doesn't report any problem with the Spark Context being null because it's wrapped in a `Try` that tosses any errors. The question is, "Do we want to remove the code or add back support for shutting down the Spark Context when the JVM is being shutdown?" Since it doesn't seem to be needed, I'm in favor of merging in this PR that just removes the failing code inside the shutdown hook.

@lbustelo, @Lull3rSkat3r, thoughts?

There is a discussion about if stop is import on the [Spark Mailing List](http://apache-spark-user-list.1001560.n3.nabble.com/SparkContext-stop-td17826.html). Matei explicitly says it is ok to not call stop. However, if the last statement is true we may want to add in the option to stop the context on shutdown.

As of now, I am in favor of merging. üëç from me, thanks for the PR!
LGTM
@fiskl, can you rebase this PR again? Want to keep the commit history relatively clean.
Rebased off the latest
LGTM

@fiskl, not sure if it matters to you, but the email address you're using for your commits doesn't seem to be associated with your Github account. Commits will go in fine, but Github won't associate them with your account unless you add the email address you used to your account.
That's a good point, git global settings + work email. Have to remember to change that, cheers

In that case, could we use a repackaged guava, or at least a more modern version? The new cassandra drivers are now refusing to work below v16, but I believe the hadoop ecosystem is stuck on v14

Thanks again for all the PRs! Loving the support!

I expect this PR will lead to a bit of back-and-forth, as it is effectively creating a new API in the python kernel object. Thought it was worth starting that discussion as I think hiding the py4j bridge as much as possible is a worthy goal

Is there any way in Python to add a "catch all" method to a class such that invocations on that class that do not match methods like `refreshContext` will be captured? I'm assuming the wrapper kernel shadows the existing one. Ideally, when not providing a wrapper method, it would be nice to fall back to the underlying kernel instance.
Seems like overriding `__getattr__` and `__setattr__` might do what you want?
Does `__getattr__` get called during method invocation as well (as in, this would look up the method and return it to then be invoked). If so, then yeah, I would think that could do it.
@fiskl, is this finished?
Yes, it is
Looks like this was already handled in #51
@poplav you are right. I will close this pull request.

Hard to give you a thought without the big picture. 
If I understand well, toree is meant to execute remotely a snippet of code (in a specified language) and return back the result? 

I am certainly very extremely naive but, does the language not coming from the message sent through the IPython communication protocol? ( https://ipython.org/ipython-doc/3/development/messaging.html#kernel-info ) Certainly given by the Notebook's cell and/or, if we want to execute our own piece of code, the message we send to the toree server?

The fact that the language_info is a Map is certainly due to that it comes from a dynamic parsing of the JSON (IPython protocol). If you want to be strict you will have to add the 3 missing fields (mimetype, codemirror_mode, nbconvert_exporter,... ) and maybe to add a comment linking to the documentation in the code.

The real challenge here would be create a "simple" ReST interface in our server to communicate with a Toree server to execute piece of code from our Web UI rights?

Unsure why this is not testing properly on jenkins.

When running tests locally on windows i get initialization issues for AddExternalJarMagicSpecForIntegration

@krishnakalyan3, we're seeing the occasional test lockup. For some reason, it's happening a little more often than I remember. You can retrigger the tests by closing and reopening your PR.

@lbustelo, @Lull3rSkat3r, I thought we had stamped out the test hangup problem. Any thoughts as to what is causing this?

@chipsenkbeil do you think the pull request looks okay?. I will close/reopen the PR. 
There were some @Experiment annotations in the file below which I did not remove `kernel/src/main/scala/org/apache/toree/kernel/api/Kernel.scala`.

At this point, you can remove all of the `@Experimental` tags that you find. Those were added at the beginning of 2015; so, I see no reason to leave them on now when they have proven to be stable and the API is pretty consistent.

Obviously, leave the experimental annotation declaration itself since we may add `@Experimental` to other APIs in the future.
@chipsenkbeil, no I don't know what could be the problem with the tests hanging. Created an issue for it: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/TOREE-326

@krishnakalyan3, did you mean to close and delete your branch? If you were trying to re-run the tests, you can just close and then reopen. No need to delete your branch. If you're having issues, let us know via the mailing list or this PR.
@lbustelo

It is strange that it decided to publish our jars under an additional folder...

https://repository.apache.org/content/repositories/snapshots/org/apache/toree/kernel/

notice the trailing `kernel` folder.

@fiskl, is this ready to be merged? Haven't been keeping up with the conversation on this one. Not sure if you had addressed @dsaradini or tackled the version retrieval that you wanted to support on the broker. I see that you've put in version information for Scala and Python while leaving SparkR and Sql TBD, which is fine.

@krishnakalyan3, can you continue to close and reopen until the tests pass? They ended up hanging again. You don't need to delete your branch. When you click close, you should have a button to reopen as well.
No - I'm happyish with the Interpreter api, but need to investigate further how to plumb the Python version up from the broker. Been too sick to tackle it this week

I am kinda tempted to simply add a method to the BrokerState that gets/sets properties, a little bit of shared memory between the parent and child processes. The pyspark_runner could then set a `languageVersion` property, and the PysparkInterpreter could use that in `languageInfo`.

I'm not across the jupyter interaction, will there be race conditions if this is done?

What do you two think?

@fiskl, we should be able to avoid race conditions, although it might take the kernel a little more time to respond if the language isn't baked into the interpreter as a constant.

While being able to get/set arbitrary properties could be useful, I think the language information should be a specific method (maybe just using property settings underneath) since that should be supported across all languages including Python and R.

First cut of this branch is ready to merge, if the build passes.

I'm simply removed version information for now, as it is not strictly required. The only required `language_info` field is `name`.

 When I communicated to version back from the broker state I ran into a race condition (or an invalid assumption). The data was requested before the broker state was set to ready, so the version never came back up.

I'll look further into it at leisure

It is a bit ugly, but you gotta do what you gotta do. In the PySpark interpreter I had to await the broker state being ready before returning the languageinfo object.

Also, treated `version` as special, forcing it to be returned when you mark the broker state as ready.

Finally, I notice that nobody ever actually calls the start method on the non-scala interpreters, it only does it internally
@chipsenkbeil Build passed, and this is now able to be merged

@Lull3rSkat3r 

I've had endless issues getting sbt to resolve properly using coursier -- so i've disabled that for now.

Okay I've changed the internals of Toree to make a SparkSession instead of a sqlContext.

All the tests pass locally for me now.  (Well aside from the 3 ignored ones).
Is there a better way to do it? I feel like the start + stop methods should be explicitly called, rather than passively initializing the interpreter?

So 2.11 scala is the "default" build now.  You can still compile spark for 2.10 (much like you could compile for 2.11 in the 1.X series).

Spark does require java8 under 2.0

Is the 2.11 support just with Spark 2.0? Or is it also for Spark 1.x? Also, with automated tests failing, does this mean that 2.11 passes those tests and 2.10 is now broken? Figuring out what the state is.
So we probably need to change the automated test stuff to use sbt +test to do all the pieces.
I'm getting some tests around %AddJar stuff, not certain what actually needs to change

Add jar uses some code specific to Scala 2.10. It was removed in 2.11, but a fix was added to later releases of 2.11 to support the same implementation. I believe it was reintroduced into Scala 2.11.5 via https://github.com/scala/scala/pull/4051. That added a different method to support dynamically adding jars (used to power the REPL).

So, we'd need to provide an implementation difference in Scala 2.10 vs. 2.11, which is doable with the version of sbt we have. Just need to provide a method that is implemented differently between the two.

The original issue that added this functionality (that we also have in the kernel) is here: https://github.com/apache/spark/pull/1929

So i'm not sure what is causing the test errors like this,

@chipsenkbeil I suspect that the remaining test failure may be due to the ScalaTestJar.jar in resources.

`scala-interpreter/src/test/resources`

How is that built?
Can we move that thing around to have a Scala2.10 and 2.11 version?

@mariusvniekerk, I can't even remember how we created that. I should have left the sources in the resource directory. I believe it had a single class with a method just to verify that adding an external jar written in Scala worked. so, yeah, we could definitely produce 2.10 and 2.11 versions. From there, we could have a test that runs for 2.10 versus 2.11. It's as easy as adding `scala-2.10` and `scala-2.11` directories to the test folder alongside `scala`, which is run for all versions of Scala.

@chipsenkbeil So it doesn't seem to be scala version related. 

I can run that test suite in intellij (and they work), just not in sbt.  
This seems to be related to something with how sbt runs these tests.

I'm going to replace the spark snaphot with the 2.0.0 released ones later this week
I would leave the experimental on. Would be nice to make the Comm API more similar to the python api.
@chipsenkbeil So all the tests pass locally.  Not sure what we want to do about the docker system-test thing since it relies on a docker image that doesn't contain spark 2.0
Sounds like it needs to be updated. I wonder if we can support both in one Docker image. @Lull3rSkat3r, @lbustelo?
Is it as simple as setting SPARK_HOME to the right version?

Yes it should be simple to allow switching inside the docker image.  This branch though does not run on pre 2.0.
We set the SPARK_HOME in the kernel_spec.

For now to get the tests to work properly on travis i'm just appending installing spark 2.0.0 during the docker based test.
I can roll the docker changes into a separate pr if this guy is getting too big.
@lbustelo okay done that.  I think the python test failure at the end is just transient?
